work .

# 4. Set focus timer
f25

Time: <30 seconds Result: Working on most important teaching task

docs.title: Workflow 2: Research Block
docs.text:

dash research

# 2. Pick specific project

# 3. Long focus session
f50

# 4. Work, then update

docs.title: Workflow 3: Package Development
docs.text:
# 1. View R packages
dash packages

# 2. Select by name
work mediationverse

# 3. R package workflow
rload
rtest
rdoc

# 4. Commit progress

status . active P0 "Testing complete" 90

Time: Varies by development Result: Incremental package progress

docs.title: Workflow 4: Weekly Review
docs.text:
# 1. See everything
dash

# 2. Review each category
dash teaching
dash research
dash packages

# 3. Update all statuses

status collider blocked P1 "Waiting" 90

# 4. Pause what you can't do this week

Time: 5-10 minutes weekly Result: Realistic priorities set

docs.title: Workflow 5: Context Switching
docs.text:
When interrupted:

# 1. Update current project
status . paused P0 "Resume after meeting" 75

# 2. Switch to urgent task
just-start

# 3. Work on it
work .
f25

# 4. Return to original
work mediationverse
status . active P0 "Resume work" 75

docs.title: Exercise 1: Balance Your Projects
docs.text:
Review your active projects and balance them.

Goal: 2-4 active projects max, rest paused/ready

Hint Run `dash`, count active projects. Pause anything not P0/P1 or not immediately actionable. Solution 
# 1. View current state
dash

# 2. Pause low-priority active projects
status medfit paused P2 "Do later" 30
status causal-inference paused P2 "Next semester" 0

# 3. Keep only critical/important active
status mediationverse active P0 "Final push" 85
status stat-440 active P0 "Urgent grading" 60
status flow-cli active P1 "Documentation" 95

# 4. Verify
dash
# Should see 2-4 active, rest paused

docs.title: Exercise 2: Category-Based Day
docs.text:
Plan a day focusing on one category.

Solution 
# Morning: Teaching focus
dash teaching
work stat-440
f50
# ... work ...
status . active P0 "Graded 20 exams" 70

# Afternoon: Research focus
dash research
work collider
f50
# ... work ...
status . active P1 "Finished analysis" 95

# Evening: Package development
dash packages
work mediationverse
f25
# ... work ...
status . active P0 "All tests pass" 90

docs.title: Exercise 3: Emergency Project
docs.text:
Handle an urgent new project without losing track of current work.

Solution 
# 1. Pause current project
cd ~/projects/current-project
status . paused P1 "Emergency interrupt - resume ASAP" 60

# 2. Create new urgent project
cd ~/projects/urgent-project
status urgent-project --create
status urgent-project active P0 "Critical fix" 0

# 3. Work on it
work .
# ... fix the issue ...
status . active P0 "Fixed critical bug" 100

# 4. Mark complete and return
status . ready P2 "Done - archive if needed" 100

# 5. Resume original work
work current-project
status . active P1 "Resume work" 60

docs.title: "Too many active projects"
docs.text:
Cause: Everything marked as active

Fix:

# Pause non-urgent projects
dash | grep ACTIVE
# Pick 2-3 most important
# Pause the rest
status project-name paused P2 "Do later" X

docs.title: "Can't decide what to work on"
docs.text:
Cause: Unclear priorities

Fix:

# Let Flow decide
just-start

# Or filter and pick
dash teaching      # Focus on one category
work stat-440      # Pick the urgent one

docs.title: "Switching too frequently"
docs.text:
Cause: No time blocks

Fix:

# Set category-based time blocks
# Morning: Teaching
dash teaching && work . && f50

# Afternoon: Research
dash research && work . && f50

# Use timers to enforce focus

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
In this tutorial, you learned:

Concept What You Did Filtering Used dash <category> to focus Switching Used work, pick, just-start States Paused, blocked, activated projects Priorities Set P0/P1/P2 realistically Workflows Category-based and priority-based

Key commands:

dash <category>    # Filter by category
just-start         # Auto-pick by priority
pick               # Fuzzy search projects
work <name>        # Switch to project
status . paused    # Pause current
status . active    # Activate project
status . blocked   # Mark blocked

Key insights:

  • 2-4 active projects max - Rest should be paused/ready
  • Use categories - Focus time on one area
  • Let Flow pick - Reduces decision fatigue
  • Update statuses - Keeps dashboard accurate

docs.title: Tutorial: Using Status Visualizations
docs.text:
What you'll build: Understanding and using visual progress indicators effectively

Time: ~15 minutes | Level: Intermediate

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before starting, you should:

  • [ ] Completed: Tutorial 2: Tracking Multiple Projects
  • [ ] Have projects with progress tracked (0-100%)
  • [ ] Understand basic status command

Verify your setup:

# Check you have projects with progress
dash | grep "%"

# Should see percentage values for projects

docs.title: What You'll Learn
docs.text:
By the end of this tutorial, you will:

  1. Read and interpret progress bars
  2. Use progress tracking to stay motivated
  3. Understand project metrics and statistics
  4. Create accurate progress estimates

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Flow CLI uses visual indicators to make progress tangible:

┌───────────────┐     ┌───────────────┐     ┌───────────────┐
│  Update %     │ --> │  See Progress │ --> │ Stay Motivated│
│  (status)     │     │   (dash)      │     │   (wins)      │
└───────────────┘     └───────────────┘     └───────────────┘

Visual feedback helps ADHD-friendly workflows by:

  • Making abstract progress concrete
  • Providing dopamine hits when bars fill up
  • Showing momentum across multiple projects

docs.title: Step 1.1: Basic Progress Display
docs.text:
View a project's progress:

dash

What you'll see:

🔥 ACTIVE NOW (3):
  📦 mediationverse [P0] 85% - Final simulations
  📚 stat-440 [P1] 60% - Grade midterms
  🔧 flow-cli [P2] 95% - Documentation

Progress breakdown:

Range Color Meaning 0-25% Red Just started 26-50% Yellow Making progress 51-75% Cyan Over halfway 76-99% Green Almost done 100% Bright Green Complete!

docs.title: Step 1.2: Detailed Progress Bars
docs.text:
Some commands show full progress bars:

# View detailed status (if implemented)
status mediationverse --show

What you might see:

📦 mediationverse
═══════════════════════════════════════════

Status:   🔥 ACTIVE
Priority: [P0] Critical
Progress: ████████████████░░░░ 85%
Task:     Final simulations
Updated:  2025-12-24

Recent progress:
  Dec 20: 60% → 70% (+10%)
  Dec 22: 70% → 80% (+10%)
  Dec 24: 80% → 85% (+5%)

docs.title: Step 1.3: Category Summaries
docs.text:
See aggregate progress:

dash teaching

What you'll see:

╭─────────────────────────────────────────────╮
│ 🎯 TEACHING PROJECTS (2)                    │
│ Average progress: 45%                       │
╰─────────────────────────────────────────────╯

🔥 ACTIVE (2):
  📚 stat-440 [P0] 60% - Grade midterms
  📚 causal-inference [P2] 30% - Prep syllabus

docs.title: Checkpoint
docs.text:
At this point, you should understand:

  • [x] Progress percentage colors
  • [x] How to view progress in dashboard
  • [x] What different ranges mean

Verify:

dash | grep "%"
# Expected: See projects with different progress levels

docs.title: Step 2.1: Starting a New Project (0%)
docs.text:
When starting fresh:

cd ~/projects/new-project
status new-project --create
status new-project ready P2 "Initial setup" 0

What happened: Project created at 0%:

📋 READY TO START (1):
  📊 new-project [P2] 0% - Initial setup

docs.title: Step 2.2: Small Incremental Updates
docs.text:
Update progress in small chunks:

# First day: Basic setup
status new-project active P2 "Setup environment" 10

# Next day: Start coding
status new-project active P2 "First feature" 25

# Week later: Halfway
status new-project active P2 "Core complete" 50

Why small increments?

  • More accurate than big jumps
  • More frequent dopamine hits
  • Easier to estimate remaining work

docs.title: Step 2.3: The 80-20 Rule
docs.text:
Many projects follow this pattern:

0-80%:   Fast progress (easy work)
80-95%:  Slow progress (hard/tedious work)
95-100%: Very slow (polish, edge cases)

Example progression:

# Week 1-2: Fast progress
status project active P1 "Core features" 80

# Week 3: Slows down
status project active P1 "Bug fixes" 85

# Week 4: Tedious work
status project active P1 "Edge cases" 90

# Week 5: Final polish
status project active P1 "Documentation" 95

# Week 6: Complete
status project ready P2 "Done!" 100

Tip: Don't be discouraged when 80-100% takes as long as 0-80%!

docs.title: Step 2.4: Progress Milestones
docs.text:
Set checkpoints:

Progress Milestone Task Example 0% Planning "Define scope and requirements" 25% Foundation "Basic setup complete" 50% Core "Main features implemented" 75% Integration "Everything connected" 90% Polish "Bug fixes and cleanup" 100% Done "Ready for release"

docs.title: Checkpoint
docs.text:
At this point, you should:

  • [x] Know how to track new projects
  • [x] Understand incremental updates
  • [x] Recognize the 80-20 pattern

Verify:

# Update a project with new milestone
status . active P1 "Reached 75% milestone" 75
dash
# Expected: See updated progress

docs.title: Step 3.1: Celebrate Progress
docs.text:
When you cross milestones:

# Hit 50%!
status . active P0 "Halfway done!" 50
win "Reached 50% on mediationverse package!"

# Hit 75%!
status . active P0 "Almost there!" 75
win "75% complete - final push!"

# Hit 100%!
status . ready P2 "Complete!" 100
win "COMPLETED mediationverse package!!!"

docs.title: Step 3.2: Track Velocity
docs.text:
How fast are you progressing?

# Monday
status project active P1 "Start work" 10

# Friday
status project active P1 "Week complete" 30

# Velocity: 20% per week
# Estimate: 3.5 weeks to complete (70% remaining / 20% per week)

Track in your task description:

status project active P1 "Week 2 - on track (+20%)" 30

docs.title: Step 3.3: Use Visual Momentum
docs.text:
Seeing multiple projects advance creates momentum:

# Before (Monday)
dash
# mediationverse: 65%
# stat-440: 40%
# flow-cli: 80%

# After (Friday)
dash
# mediationverse: 75% ⬆️ +10%
# stat-440: 60% ⬆️ +20%
# flow-cli: 90% ⬆️ +10%

win "Productive week! All projects advanced!"

docs.title: Step 3.4: Handle Setbacks
docs.text:
Sometimes progress goes backward:

# Discovered major bug, need to redo work
status project active P0 "Fix critical bug - set back" 70

# Previous was 85%, now 70% (-15%)

This is OK! Accurate progress > inflated numbers.

docs.title: Checkpoint
docs.text:
At this point, you should:

  • [x] Celebrate milestones with win
  • [x] Track velocity (% per week)
  • [x] Use visual momentum
  • [x] Handle setbacks honestly

Verify:

wins
# Expected: See celebration wins for milestones

docs.title: Technique 1: Sub-Project Breakdown
docs.text:
For large projects, track components:

# Main project
status mediationverse active P0 "Package development" 75

# Mental breakdown (not tracked in tool):
# - Core functions: 90% (mostly done)
# - Tests: 80% (good coverage)
# - Documentation: 60% (needs work)
# - Vignettes: 50% (in progress)
# Average: (90+80+60+50)/4 = 70%

# Update based on weighted average
status mediationverse active P0 "Focus on docs/vignettes" 70

docs.title: Technique 2: Must-Have vs Nice-to-Have
docs.text:
Adjust progress based on scope:

# Original plan (100% = everything)
status project active P1 "All features" 60

# Scope reduction (100% = must-haves only)
status project active P1 "Core features only" 85

# Suddenly much closer to done!

docs.title: Technique 3: Time-Based vs Work-Based
docs.text:
Two ways to track:

Time-based (not recommended):

# Week 1 of 10 = 10%
status project active P1 "Week 1" 10

Work-based (recommended):

# 3 of 10 features done = 30%
status project active P1 "3/10 features" 30

Tip: Work-based is more accurate because work rarely distributes evenly over time.

docs.title: Technique 4: Done is Better Than Perfect
docs.text:
Don't wait for 100% perfection:

# 95% complete, could polish forever
status project active P1 "Good enough to ship" 95

# Ship it!
status project ready P2 "Shipped v1.0!" 100
win "Shipped project v1.0 - done is better than perfect!"

# Future improvements are a new project
status project-v2 ready P2 "Enhancements for v2" 0

docs.title: Exercise 1: Estimate a New Project
docs.text:
Break down and estimate a new project.

Hint List all major tasks, estimate time for each, calculate total, set milestones. Solution 
# New R package project
cd ~/projects/r-packages/active/newpackage

# Break down tasks:
# 1. Setup (5%) - 1 day
# 2. Core functions (30%) - 1 week
# 3. Tests (20%) - 3 days
# 4. Documentation (20%) - 3 days
# 5. Vignettes (15%) - 2 days
# 6. Final checks (10%) - 1 day

# Start tracking
status newpackage ready P2 "Planning complete" 0

# After setup
status newpackage active P1 "Package skeleton created" 5

# After core
status newpackage active P1 "Main functions working" 35

# Continue incrementally...

docs.title: Exercise 2: Recover from Setback
docs.text:
Handle a project that went backwards.

Solution 
# Before: thought you were at 80%
status project active P0 "Found major issue" 80

# After analysis: need to redo significant work
status project active P0 "Revising approach - realistic reset" 60

# Document why
win "Discovered issue early - better to fix now than later"

# Make steady progress forward
status project active P0 "Fixed root cause" 70
status project active P0 "Re-implemented correctly" 80
status project active P0 "Validated thoroughly" 90
status project ready P2 "Done right this time!" 100

docs.title: Exercise 3: Celebrate Milestones
docs.text:
Track and celebrate a project's key milestones.

Solution 
# 0%: Start
status project active P1 "Project started" 0
win "Started new project - excited to build this!"

# 25%: Foundation
status project active P1 "Foundation solid" 25
win "25% complete - strong foundation!"

# 50%: Halfway
status project active P1 "Halfway there!" 50
win "50% COMPLETE! - past the hardest part!"

# 75%: Polish phase
status project active P1 "Polishing now" 75
win "75% done - can see the finish line!"

# 100%: Complete
status project ready P2 "DONE!" 100
win "PROJECT COMPLETE! Shipped and proud!"

# View all celebrations
wins

docs.title: "Progress seems stuck"
docs.text:
Cause: Working on 80-100% phase (slow progress)

Fix:

# Break down remaining work into smaller tasks
# Update more frequently with smaller increments

# Instead of jumping from 85% to 90%:
status . active P1 "Fixed bug #1" 86
status . active P1 "Fixed bug #2" 87
status . active P1 "Added validation" 88

# Smaller wins feel better!

docs.title: "Not sure what percentage to use"
docs.text:
Cause: Unclear milestones

Fix:

# Use concrete milestones:
# 0%   = Planning
# 10%  = Setup complete
# 25%  = First feature working
# 50%  = Core features done
# 75%  = All features implemented
# 90%  = Testing/polish
# 100% = Complete and shipped

# Estimate based on work done vs work remaining

docs.title: "Progress feels arbitrary"
docs.text:
Cause: Not tracking concrete deliverables

Fix:

# Track specific completions:
status . active P1 "3 of 10 functions complete" 30
status . active P1 "7 of 15 tests passing" 47
status . active P1 "2 of 4 vignettes written" 80

# % = (completed / total) * 100

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
In this tutorial, you learned:

Concept What You Did Progress ranges Understood 0-25%, 26-50%, 51-75%, 76-99%, 100% Incremental tracking Updated in small chunks for accuracy The 80-20 rule Expected 80-100% to be slow Milestones Set and celebrated progress markers Motivation Used visual progress for dopamine Estimates Broke down work to calculate %

Key insights:

# Track progress incrementally
status . active P1 "Task complete (+5%)" 35

# Celebrate milestones
win "Reached 50%!"

# Be honest about setbacks
status . active P0 "Reset to fix properly" 60

# Ship at 95-100%, don't wait for perfection
status . ready P2 "Good enough!" 100

Progress tips:

  • Small increments - 5-10% updates feel more concrete
  • Celebrate milestones - 25%, 50%, 75%, 100%
  • Accept setbacks - Accurate % > inflated numbers
  • Ship it - 95%+ is often "done enough"

docs.text:

docs.title: Tutorial 5: AI-Powered Commands
docs.text: Time: 10 minutes Prerequisites: flow-cli installed, Claude CLI (claude) available Goal: Use AI to accelerate your workflow

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
flow-cli v3.2.0 introduces AI-powered commands that use Claude to help you:

  • Ask questions with project context (flow ai)
  • Translate natural language to shell commands (flow do)
  • Get unstuck with AI assistance (stuck --ai)
  • Get smart task suggestions (next --ai)

docs.title: Step 1: Check Prerequisites
docs.text:
First, verify Claude CLI is installed:

command -v claude && echo "✅ Claude CLI found" || echo "❌ Install: npm i -g @anthropic-ai/claude-code"

docs.title: Basic Query
docs.text:
Ask AI anything about your project:

flow ai "what testing framework should I use for this project?"

The AI receives context about:

  • Your current directory
  • Project type (ZSH plugin, R package, etc.)
  • Git branch and status
  • Active flow session

docs.title: Explain Mode
docs.text:
Get explanations of code or concepts:

flow ai --explain "what does this regex do: ^##\s*Focus:"

docs.title: Fix Mode
docs.text:
Get help fixing problems:

flow ai --fix "my tests are failing with 'command not found'"

docs.title: Suggest Mode
docs.text:
Get improvement suggestions:

flow ai --suggest "make this function more efficient"

docs.title: Create Mode
docs.text:
Generate code from descriptions:

flow ai --create "a function that validates email addresses"

docs.title: Step 3: Natural Language Commands
docs.text: The flow do command translates plain English into shell commands.

docs.title: Try These Examples
docs.text:
# Show recent git activity
flow do "show commits from last week"

# Find files
flow do "find all markdown files modified today"

# Count code
flow do "count lines of code in zsh files"

# Check disk usage
flow do "show largest files in current directory"

docs.title: Dry Run Mode
docs.text:
See what command would run without executing:

flow do --dry-run "delete all .bak files"

Output:

🔍 Translating: "delete all .bak files"
📝 Command: find . -name "*.bak" -delete

⚠️  DRY RUN - command not executed

docs.title: Safety Features
docs.text:
Dangerous commands require confirmation:

flow do "remove all files"

Output:

⚠️  DANGEROUS COMMAND DETECTED
📝 Command: rm -rf *

This command could cause data loss.
Execute anyway? [y/N]:

docs.title: When You're Stuck
docs.text:
# Get general unstuck tips
stuck

# Get AI-powered help
stuck --ai

# Describe your specific problem
stuck --ai "can't figure out why the tests pass locally but fail in CI"

The AI will:

  1. Break down the problem into tiny steps
  2. Suggest ONE specific action to start
  3. Offer to capture the problem for later

docs.title: What to Work on Next
docs.text:
# See your active projects
next

# Get AI-powered suggestion
next --ai

The AI considers:

  • Your active projects and their focus
  • Inbox items waiting
  • Energy management for ADHD

docs.title: Include Extra Context
docs.text:
Force context inclusion even for simple queries:

flow ai --context "should I use async here?"

docs.title: Verbose Mode
docs.text:
See what context is being sent to AI:

flow ai --verbose "how do I add a new command?"

Output:

📋 Context being sent:
Directory: /Users/dt/projects/dev-tools/flow-cli
Project type: zsh-plugin
Git branch: main
Changed files: 3
...

🤖 Asking AI...

docs.title: Combine Modes
docs.text:
# Explain with context
flow ai --explain --context "the _flow_detect_type function"

# Fix with verbose output
flow ai --fix --verbose "completion not working"

docs.title: Quick Reference
docs.text: Command Purpose flow ai "query" Ask AI anything flow ai --explain Explain code/concepts flow ai --fix Get fix suggestions flow ai --suggest Get improvements flow ai --create Generate code flow do "..." Natural language → shell flow do --dry-run Preview without executing stuck --ai AI help when blocked next --ai AI task suggestion

docs.title: Tips for ADHD Brains
docs.text:
1. Use flow do for commands you can't remember
  2. Don't waste mental energy on syntax

  3. Just describe what you want

  4. stuck --ai is your rubber duck

  5. Describing the problem often reveals the solution

  6. AI breaks it into manageable pieces

  7. next --ai helps with decision paralysis

  8. When everything feels equally important

  9. Get ONE clear recommendation

  10. Dry run everything dangerous

  11. flow do --dry-run before destructive operations
  12. Builds confidence before executing

docs.title: "Claude CLI not found"
docs.text:
Install with:

npm install -g @anthropic-ai/claude-code

docs.title: AI responses are slow
docs.text:
• Claude CLI makes API calls - expect 1-3 seconds
  • Use --verbose to see progress

docs.title: Commands not translating correctly
docs.text:
• Be more specific in your description
  • Use --dry-run to see what it would do
  • Adjust and try again

docs.title: What's Next?
docs.text:
• Tutorial 6: Custom workflows (coming soon)
  • Reference: COMMAND-QUICK-REFERENCE.md
  • Help: flow ai --help, flow do --help

docs.title: Tutorial: Dopamine Features for Motivation
docs.text:
What you'll learn: How to use win tracking, streaks, and goals to stay motivated

Time: ~20 minutes | Level: Beginner

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before starting, you should:

  • [ ] Have completed Tutorial 1: Your First Session
  • [ ] Know how to use work and finish commands
  • [ ] Have at least one project to work on

docs.title: What You'll Learn
docs.text:
By the end of this tutorial, you will:

  1. Log wins and celebrate accomplishments
  2. Understand win categories and auto-detection
  3. Track your streak and daily progress
  4. Set and monitor daily goals
  5. Use the dashboard to visualize your progress

docs.title: Why Dopamine Features?
docs.text:
For ADHD minds, small visible rewards are essential for sustained focus:

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│  Do Something  →  Log Win  →  See Progress  →  Repeat  │
│      🎯              🎉            📊           🔄      │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

Each win gives you a dopamine boost, making it easier to keep going.

docs.title: Step 1.1: Complete Something (Anything!)
docs.text:
First, do some work. It could be small:

  • Fixed a typo
  • Wrote one function
  • Read some documentation
  • Replied to an email

docs.title: Step 1.2: Log the Win
docs.text:
win "Fixed the typo in README"

What happened: You logged your first win! The output shows:

🎉 WIN LOGGED! #docs
Fixed the typo in README

Keep it up! 🚀

Notice how it detected the category #docs from the word "README".

docs.title: Step 1.3: Try Different Categories
docs.text:
Log a few more wins with different keywords:

win "Deployed the new homepage"
# → 🚀 ship (detected "deployed")

win "Fixed login bug"
# → 🔧 fix (detected "fixed")

win "Added unit tests for auth module"
# → 🧪 test (detected "tests")

docs.title: Category Auto-Detection
docs.text:
Flow CLI automatically categorizes wins based on keywords:

Category Icon Trigger Words code 💻 implement, add, create, build, refactor docs 📝 doc, readme, guide, tutorial, comment review 👀 review, pr, feedback, approve ship 🚀 deploy, release, ship, publish, merge fix 🔧 fix, bug, issue, resolve, patch test 🧪 test, spec, coverage, passing other ✨ (default if no keywords match)

docs.title: Manual Category Override
docs.text:
Sometimes auto-detection doesn't match your intent:

# Force a specific category
win --code "Wrote utility function"
win -f "Resolved edge case"    # -f = fix
win --ship "Merged feature branch"

When to Override

Use manual categories when: - Keywords are ambiguous ("added docs" → is it code or docs?) - You want a specific categorization for tracking - Auto-detection missed the context

docs.title: Recent Wins
docs.text:
yay

Output:

🎉 Recent Wins
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
Total: 3 wins | Streak: 🔥 5 days

docs.title: Weekly Summary
docs.text:
yay --week

Output:

📊 This Week's Wins

🚀 Deployed v2.0 to production
💻 Implemented OAuth login
🧪 Added integration tests
🔧 Fixed race condition
📝 Updated installation docs

─────────────────────────────────────
🚀2 💻3 🔧1 📝1 = 7 wins this week

Mon Tue Wed Thu Fri Sat Sun
 ▁   ▃   ██  ▅   ▂
     Activity Graph

Celebrate Your Progress

The weekly summary shows your work patterns. Seeing your wins visualized helps reinforce the habit.

docs.title: What's a Streak?
docs.text:
A streak counts consecutive days with at least one work session.

Streak Visual Meaning 0-2 🌱 Building momentum 3-6 🔥 On a roll 7-13 🔥🔥 Strong week 14+ 🔥🔥🔥 Exceptional streak

docs.title: Viewing Your Streak
docs.text:
Your streak appears in several places:

# In the dashboard
dash

# In the win display
yay

# In extended status
status --extended

docs.title: Building a Streak
docs.text:
Day 1: work project → 🌱 1 day streak
Day 2: work project → 🌱 2 days
Day 3: work project → 🔥 3 days - On a roll!
Day 4: (no work)    → 😢 Streak reset
Day 5: work project → 🌱 1 day (starting over)

Maintain Your Streak

Even a 5-minute session counts! On busy days, do a quick work → win "Quick check-in" → finish to keep your streak alive.

docs.title: Set Your First Goal
docs.text:
# Set a goal of 3 wins per day
flow goal set 3

Output:

🎯 Daily goal set: 3 wins

docs.title: Check Your Progress
docs.text:
flow goal

Output:

🎯 Today's Progress
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
██████░░░░ 2/3 wins

Log 1 more win to reach your goal!

docs.title: Goal Shown in Dashboard
docs.text:
The dashboard now shows your goal progress:

dash

┌─ 🎉 Recent Wins ─────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ 🎯 Daily Goal: ██████░░░░ 2/3                                │
│                                                              │
│ 💻 Implemented auth service              14:20               │
│ 🔧 Fixed login redirect bug              11:45               │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

docs.title: Adjusting Your Goal
docs.text:
Start small and increase as you build the habit:

# Start conservatively
flow goal set 2

# After a week of hitting goals
flow goal set 3

# If you're crushing it
flow goal set 5

docs.title: Part 6: Per-Project Goals
docs.text: You can set different goals for different projects.

docs.title: Add to .STATUS File
docs.text:
Open your project's .STATUS file:

## Project: my-project

## Status: active

## daily_goal: 5

docs.title: How Priority Works
docs.text:
1. Project .STATUS → daily_goal field (highest priority)
  2. Global goal → flow goal set N
  3. Default → 3 wins

docs.title: Interactive Dashboard
docs.text:
dash -i

Keyboard shortcuts:

Key Action Enter Open project Ctrl-W Log a win Ctrl-E Edit .STATUS file ? Show help Esc Exit

docs.title: Part 8: Complete Workflow
docs.text:
Here's how dopamine features fit into your daily routine:

# Morning: Check your state
morning
# or
dash

# Start working
work my-project

# Log wins as you go (don't wait!)
win "Fixed authentication bug"
win "Added input validation"

# Check progress mid-day
flow goal

# More work...
win "Completed user profile feature"

# End of session
finish "Good progress today"

# Check your streak
yay

docs.title: 1. Log Wins Immediately
docs.text:
Don't wait until the end of the day:

# Right after finishing something
win "Just fixed that annoying bug"

The immediate feedback reinforces the behavior.

docs.title: 2. Keep Goals Achievable
docs.text:
Start small. A goal you hit daily is better than an ambitious goal you miss:

# Week 1
flow goal set 2

# Week 2 (if consistently hitting)
flow goal set 3

docs.title: 3. Use Categories
docs.text:
Categories help you see patterns:

  • Lots of 🔧 fix? Maybe time for some proactive work.
  • All 💻 code and no 📝 docs? Documentation week!
  • Heavy 👀 review? Balance with creation time.

docs.title: 4. Check Dashboard Daily
docs.text:
Make dash part of your morning:

morning    # Morning routine with suggestions
dash       # Quick dashboard check

docs.title: Wins Not Showing

# Check wins file exists
ls -la ~/.local/share/flow/wins.md

# View raw file
cat ~/.local/share/flow/wins.md

docs.title: Streak Reset Unexpectedly
docs.text:
Streaks require at least one work session per day:

# Check worklog for gaps
tail -20 ~/.local/share/flow/worklog

docs.title: Goal Not Updating
docs.text:
# Check global goal
cat ~/.local/share/flow/goal.json

# Check project-specific goal
grep daily_goal .STATUS

docs.text:
Now that you're tracking wins and building streaks:

  1. Tutorial 7: Sync Command - Keep everything in sync
  2. Workflow Quick Reference - Full command reference
  3. Dopamine Features Guide - Deep dive reference

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
Concept Command Purpose Log win win "text" Record accomplishment View wins yay, yay --week See recent wins Set goal flow goal set N Daily win target Check goal flow goal See progress View streak dash, yay Consecutive days Categories Auto or --code, etc. Organize wins

Remember: The goal isn't to optimize productivity metrics - it's to make work feel more rewarding so you can sustain focus and momentum.

docs.title: Tutorial: The Sync Command
docs.text:
What you'll learn: How to use flow sync to keep your data synchronized

Time: ~15 minutes | Level: Intermediate

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before starting, you should:

  • [ ] Have completed Tutorial 1: Your First Session
  • [ ] Have worked on at least one project with work/finish
  • [ ] Have logged some wins with win

docs.title: What You'll Learn
docs.text:
By the end of this tutorial, you will:

  1. Understand what sync does and why it matters
  2. Use smart sync to detect what needs syncing
  3. Sync specific targets (session, status, wins, goals, git)
  4. Preview changes with dry-run mode
  5. Set up scheduled automatic sync

docs.title: Why Sync?
docs.text:
Flow CLI tracks data in multiple places:

┌──────────────┐   ┌──────────────┐   ┌──────────────┐
│  Session     │   │  .STATUS     │   │  Wins        │
│  (worklog)   │   │  (per-proj)  │   │  (global)    │
└──────────────┘   └──────────────┘   └──────────────┘
        │                  │                  │
        └──────────────────┼──────────────────┘
                           │
                    ┌──────┴──────┐
                    │ flow sync   │
                    │ all         │
                    └─────────────┘

The sync command orchestrates keeping all this data consistent.

docs.title: Check What Needs Syncing
docs.text:
Run sync without arguments to see the current state:

flow sync

Output:

🔄 Sync Status

Today's progress: 2/3 wins

Suggested sync targets:
• git: 3 uncommitted changes
• status: 2 projects not updated today

Run: flow sync all

docs.title: Sync Everything
docs.text:
flow sync all

Output:

🔄 Syncing all
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

[1/5] session... done (45m on flow-cli)
[2/5] status... done (2 projects updated)
[3/5] wins... done (all wins synced)
[4/5] goals... done (2/3 (67%))
[5/5] git... done (pushed 3 commits)

✓ Sync complete (2s)

docs.title: Part 2: Sync Targets
docs.text: You can sync specific targets individually:

docs.title: Session Sync
docs.text:
Persists your current session data to the worklog:

flow sync session

Output:

45m on flow-cli

docs.title: Status Sync
docs.text:
Updates .STATUS timestamps and streaks for active projects:

flow sync status

Output:

2 projects updated

docs.title: Wins Sync
docs.text:
Aggregates project wins to the global wins file:

flow sync wins

Output:

3 new wins aggregated

docs.title: Goals Sync
docs.text:
Recalculates daily goal progress:

flow sync goals

Output:

2/3 (67%)

docs.title: Git Sync
docs.text:
Smart git sync with stash handling:

flow sync git

Output:

pushed 3 commits

What git sync does:

  1. Stashes uncommitted changes (if any)
  2. Fetches from remote
  3. Rebases onto remote branch
  4. Pushes local commits
  5. Pops stash to restore changes

docs.title: Part 3: Preview with Dry Run
docs.text:
Before syncing, preview what will happen:

flow sync all --dry-run

Output:

🔄 Syncing all
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

🔍 Dry run - no changes will be made

[1/5] session... Would log: 45m on flow-cli
[2/5] status... Would update: flow-cli
                Would skip: 12 (up to date)
[3/5] wins... Would add: Implemented auth
              Would add: Fixed login bug
[4/5] goals... Current: 2/3 (67%)
[5/5] git... Branch: main
             Would stash: 3 changes
             Would: fetch, rebase, push

Run without --dry-run to execute

Use Dry Run First

Always run --dry-run before syncing if you're unsure what will happen.

docs.title: Skip Git (Quick Local Sync)
docs.text:
When you just want to sync local data quickly:

flow sync all --skip-git

This skips the git sync target, which can be slow if you have network issues.

docs.title: Verbose Mode
docs.text:
See detailed output:

flow sync all --verbose

docs.title: Quiet Mode
docs.text:
Minimal output for scripts:

flow sync all --quiet

docs.title: Part 5: Scheduled Sync
docs.text: Set up automatic background sync using macOS launchd.

docs.title: Check Schedule Status
docs.text:
flow sync schedule

Output:

⏰ Sync Schedule Status

Status: Not configured

Run 'flow sync schedule enable [minutes]' to start

docs.title: Enable Scheduled Sync
docs.text:
# Every 30 minutes (default)
flow sync schedule enable

# Every 15 minutes
flow sync schedule enable 15

# Every hour
flow sync schedule enable 60

Output:

⏰ Enabling Sync Schedule

✓ Schedule enabled
Interval: Every 30 minutes
Targets: session, status, wins, goals (git skipped)

View logs: flow sync schedule logs
Disable: flow sync schedule disable

Git Skipped

Scheduled sync skips git because it may require user interaction (merge conflicts, auth).

docs.title: View Schedule Logs
docs.text:
flow sync schedule logs

Output:

📋 Sync Schedule Logs

Last 20 entries:

2025-12-27 14:30:00 Sync completed
2025-12-27 14:00:00 Sync completed
2025-12-27 13:30:00 Sync completed

docs.title: Disable Scheduled Sync
docs.text:
flow sync schedule disable

Output:

⏰ Disabling Sync Schedule

✓ Schedule disabled
Plist removed

docs.title: Part 6: Sync Dashboard
docs.text:
View your sync history:

flow sync --status

Output:

📊 Sync Dashboard

Last full sync: 2025-12-27T14:30:00Z

Run 'flow sync all' to sync everything

docs.title: Daily Workflow
docs.text:
# Morning: Quick sync check
flow sync

# If things need syncing
flow sync all

# End of day: Full sync including git
flow sync all

docs.title: Before Switching Computers
docs.text:
Make sure everything is synced:

flow sync all

docs.title: After Extended Break
docs.text:
Check what's stale and sync:

# See what needs syncing
flow sync

# Sync everything
flow sync all

# Check your dashboard
dash

docs.title: CI/Automation
docs.text:
For scripts, use quiet mode:

flow sync all --quiet --skip-git

docs.title: Sync Order
docs.text:
The sync runs in dependency order:

session → status → wins → goals → git
   1        2        3       4      5
  1. Session - Capture current session first
  2. Status - Update project statuses
  3. Wins - Aggregate wins (needs status data)
  4. Goals - Calculate progress (needs wins data)
  5. Git - Push everything (last, may fail)

docs.title: Git Sync Failed
docs.text:
# Check git status manually
git status

# If conflicts, resolve them
git rebase --continue
# or
git rebase --abort

# Then retry
flow sync git

docs.title: Sync Takes Too Long
docs.text:
Skip git for quick local sync:

flow sync all --skip-git

docs.title: Scheduled Sync Not Running
docs.text:
Check if the launch agent is loaded:

launchctl list | grep flow

If not listed, re-enable:

flow sync schedule enable

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Command Purpose flow sync Smart status check flow sync all Sync everything flow sync <target> Sync specific target flow sync all --dry-run Preview changes flow sync all --skip-git Quick local sync flow sync schedule enable Enable automated sync flow sync schedule disable Disable automated sync flow sync schedule logs View sync history

docs.title: What's Next?
docs.text:
Now that you understand sync:

  1. FAQ - Common questions and troubleshooting
  2. Command Quick Reference - All commands
  3. Workflow Quick Reference - Common workflows

docs.title: Related
docs.text:

docs.title: Tutorial: Git Feature Branch Workflow
docs.text:
What you'll learn: Use the feature branch workflow to safely develop and merge changes

Time: ~15 minutes | Level: Intermediate Version: v4.1.0+

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before starting, you should:

  • [ ] Completed: Tutorial 1: Your First Flow Session
  • [ ] Have a git repository with main and dev branches
  • [ ] Understand basic git concepts (branches, commits, PRs)

Verify your setup:

# Check g dispatcher is available
g help

# Check you have main and dev branches
git branch -a | grep -E "main|dev"

docs.title: What You'll Learn
docs.text:
By the end of this tutorial, you will:

  1. Create feature branches from dev
  2. Keep features synced with dev
  3. Create PRs using the proper workflow
  4. Clean up merged branches

docs.title: The Workflow Pattern
docs.text:
feature/* ──► dev ──► main
    │          │        │
    └── PR ────┘        │
               └── PR ──┘

Key Rules:

  • Never push directly to main or dev
  • All work happens on feature/*, hotfix/*, or bugfix/* branches
  • Use PRs to merge changes up the chain

docs.title: Step 1.1: Create a Feature Branch
docs.text:
# Start a new feature from dev
g feature start auth-improvements

What happened:

✅ Created feature/auth-improvements from dev
📍 Now on: feature/auth-improvements

This:

  • Fetches latest dev
  • Creates feature/auth-improvements from dev
  • Switches to the new branch

docs.title: Step 1.2: Verify Your Branch
docs.text:
# Check current branch
g

Output:

On branch feature/auth-improvements
nothing to commit, working tree clean

docs.title: Step 2.1: Make Changes and Commit
docs.text:
# Make your changes...
# Then commit
g add .
g commit "Add OAuth2 support"

docs.title: Step 2.2: Keep in Sync with Dev
docs.text:
While you work, dev may have new changes. Stay synced:

# Rebase your feature onto latest dev
g feature sync

What happened:

✅ Rebased feature/auth-improvements onto dev
📊 Your branch is 3 commits ahead of dev

Tip: Run g feature sync daily to avoid big merge conflicts!

docs.title: Step 2.3: Push Your Feature
docs.text:
# Push to remote
g push

The workflow guard will let this through because you're on a feature branch.

docs.title: Step 3.1: PR to Dev (Promote)
docs.text:
When your feature is ready:

# Create PR: feature → dev
g promote

What happened:

Creating PR: feature/auth-improvements → dev

✅ PR #42 created
   https://github.com/user/repo/pull/42

docs.title: Step 3.2: PR to Main (Release)
docs.text:
Once changes are tested in dev:

# First, switch to dev
git checkout dev

# Create PR: dev → main
g release

What happened:

Creating PR: dev → main

✅ PR #43 created
   https://github.com/user/repo/pull/43

docs.title: Step 4.1: Finish a Feature
docs.text:
Push and create PR in one command:

# Push + create PR to dev
g feature finish

What happened:

📤 Pushing feature/auth-improvements...
✅ Created PR #42: feature/auth-improvements → dev

docs.title: Step 4.2: Clean Up Merged Branches
docs.text:
After your PRs are merged:

# See what would be deleted
g feature prune -n

# Actually delete merged branches
g feature prune

# Also clean remote tracking branches
g feature prune --all

Output:

🧹 Cleaning merged feature branches...

Will delete:
  feature/auth-improvements (merged to dev)
  feature/old-feature (merged to dev)

Delete 2 branches? [y/N] y

✅ Deleted 2 merged branches

docs.title: What It Does
docs.text:
The workflow guard protects main and dev from direct pushes:

# Try to push to main (blocked)
git checkout main
g push

Output:

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
⛔ Direct push to 'main' blocked
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

Workflow: feature/* → dev → main

Commands:
  g promote    Create PR: feature → dev
  g release    Create PR: dev → main

Override: GIT_WORKFLOW_SKIP=1 git push

docs.title: Override When Needed
docs.text:
For emergencies only:

# Skip the guard (use sparingly!)
GIT_WORKFLOW_SKIP=1 git push

docs.title: Quick Reference
docs.text: Command Description g feature start <name> Create feature branch from dev g feature sync Rebase feature onto dev g feature list List feature/hotfix branches g feature finish Push + create PR to dev g feature prune Delete merged branches g promote Create PR: feature → dev g release Create PR: dev → main

docs.title: Scenario 1: Starting New Work
docs.text:
g feature start new-feature    # Create branch
# ... make changes ...
g add . && g commit "message"  # Commit
g feature finish               # Push + PR

docs.title: Scenario 2: Hotfix Needed
docs.text:
g feature start hotfix/urgent-fix  # Use hotfix/ prefix
# ... fix the issue ...
g promote                          # PR to dev
g release                          # PR to main (after dev merge)

docs.title: Scenario 3: Weekly Cleanup
docs.text:
g feature list                 # See all feature branches
g feature prune --all          # Clean merged + remote

docs.title: "Branch already exists"
docs.text:
# Delete old branch first
git branch -d feature/old-name
g feature start new-name

docs.title: "Rebase conflicts"
docs.text:
# During g feature sync, if conflicts:
# 1. Fix conflicts in files
# 2. git add <fixed-files>
# 3. git rebase --continue

docs.title: "PR creation failed"
docs.text:
# Check gh is authenticated
gh auth status

# Re-authenticate if needed
gh auth login

docs.title: What's Next?
docs.text:
• Tutorial 9: Worktrees - Parallel development with worktrees
  • Git Dispatcher Reference - All g commands
  • V4.3 Roadmap - Upcoming features

Tip: Start with g feature start for every new piece of work. It keeps your branches organized and your workflow clean!

docs.title: Tutorial: Git Worktrees for Parallel Development
docs.text:
What you'll learn: Use git worktrees to work on multiple branches simultaneously

Time: ~10 minutes | Level: Intermediate Version: v5.13.0+

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before starting, you should:

  • [ ] Completed: Tutorial 1: Your First Flow Session
  • [ ] Understand basic git concepts (branches, commits)
  • [ ] Have fzf installed (optional, for pickers)

Verify your setup:

# Check wt dispatcher is available
wt help

# Check cc wt integration
cc wt help

docs.title: What You'll Learn
docs.text:
By the end of this tutorial, you will:

  1. Create and manage git worktrees
  2. Launch Claude Code in dedicated worktrees
  3. Work on multiple features in parallel
  4. Clean up worktrees when done

docs.title: Why Worktrees?
docs.text:
The Problem:

# Traditional approach (context switching)
git stash                    # Save current work
git checkout feature-b       # Switch branches
# ... work ...
git checkout feature-a       # Switch back
git stash pop                # Restore work

The Worktree Solution:

# Parallel development (no context switching!)
~/project/              # Main worktree (feature-a)
~/.git-worktrees/
  └── project/
      └── feature-b/    # Second worktree (feature-b)

Each worktree is a separate directory with its own working copy.

docs.title: Step 1.1: List Existing Worktrees
docs.text:
wt list

Output:

/Users/you/projects/myproject  abc1234 [main]

docs.title: Step 1.2: Create a Worktree
docs.text:
# Create worktree for existing branch
wt create feature/auth

# Or for a new branch (auto-creates)
wt create feature/new-thing

What happened:

✓ Created worktree: ~/.git-worktrees/myproject/feature-auth

Navigate: cd ~/.git-worktrees/myproject/feature-auth

docs.title: Step 1.3: View Worktree Overview
docs.text:
NEW in v5.13.0 - Get a formatted overview with status and session indicators:

# View all worktrees with status icons and session indicators
wt

Output:

🌳 Worktrees (3 total)

BRANCH              STATUS   SESSION  PATH
──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
feature/auth        ✅ active  🟢 5m   ~/.git-worktrees/myproject/feature-auth
feature/dashboard   🧹 merged  🟡 2h   ~/.git-worktrees/myproject/feature-dashboard
main                🏠 main    ⚪      /Users/you/projects/myproject

💡 Filter: wt <project> | Interactive picker: pick wt (Tab=multi-select, Ctrl-X=delete, Ctrl-R=refresh)

Status Icons: - ✅ active - Unmerged feature branch - 🧹 merged - Branch merged to base - ⚠️ stale - Missing .git directory - 🏠 main - Main/master/dev branch

Session Indicators: - 🟢 active - Claude session running (< 30 min) - 🟡 recent - Recent activity (< 24h) - ⚪ none - No session

docs.title: Step 1.4: Filter by Project
docs.text:
# Show only flow-cli worktrees
wt flow

docs.title: Step 1.5: Navigate to Worktrees Folder
docs.text:
# Go to worktrees base directory (use 'cd')
wt cd

Output:

ℹ Changed to: /Users/you/.git-worktrees

docs.title: Step 2.1: Launch Claude in a Worktree
docs.text:
# Launch Claude in worktree (creates if needed!)
cc wt feature/auth

What happened:

ℹ Creating worktree for feature/auth...
✓ Created worktree: ~/.git-worktrees/myproject/feature-auth
✓ Launching Claude in ~/.git-worktrees/myproject/feature-auth

Claude Code opens in the worktree directory, completely isolated from your main work.

docs.title: Step 2.2: Pick from Existing Worktrees
docs.text:
# fzf picker for worktrees
cc wt pick

A picker appears showing all worktrees. Select one to launch Claude there.

docs.title: Step 2.3: Mode Chaining
docs.text:
Combine worktrees with Claude modes:

# YOLO mode in worktree
cc wt yolo feature/risky

# Plan mode in worktree
cc wt plan feature/complex

# Opus model in worktree
cc wt opus feature/important

# Haiku model in worktree
cc wt haiku feature/quick

docs.title: Built-in Aliases
docs.text:
ccw feature/auth     # = cc wt feature/auth
ccwy feature/auth    # = cc wt yolo feature/auth
ccwp                 # = cc wt pick

docs.title: Quick Reference
docs.text: Alias Expands To Description ccw cc wt Worktree + Claude ccwy cc wt yolo Worktree + YOLO mode ccwp cc wt pick Worktree picker

docs.title: Part 4: Interactive Worktree Management
docs.text: NEW in v5.13.0 - Interactive picker with batch operations:

docs.title: Step 4.1: Launch Interactive Picker
docs.text:
# Interactive worktree picker with actions
pick wt

The picker shows all worktrees with status icons and session indicators. You can:

  • Filter - Type to search worktrees
  • Tab - Multi-select worktrees for batch operations
  • Ctrl-X - Delete selected worktree(s)
  • Ctrl-R - Refresh cache and show updated overview
  • Enter - Navigate to selected worktree

docs.title: Step 4.2: Delete Worktrees
docs.text:
In the picker:

  1. Select worktrees with Tab
  2. Press Ctrl-X to delete

You'll be prompted:

Delete worktree: ~/.git-worktrees/myproject/feature-old? [y/n/a/q]
  • y - Yes, delete this one
  • n - No, skip this one
  • a - Yes to all remaining
  • q - Quit, don't delete any more

After deleting worktree, you'll be asked:

Also delete branch 'feature-old'? [y/N]

docs.title: Step 4.3: Refresh Cache
docs.text:
Press Ctrl-R in the picker to:

  1. Clear the project cache
  2. Show updated overview with current status

Useful after making git changes outside the picker.

docs.title: Step 5.1: Remove a Worktree
docs.text:
# Remove specific worktree
wt remove ~/.git-worktrees/myproject/feature-auth

Output:

✓ Removed worktree: ~/.git-worktrees/myproject/feature-auth

docs.title: Step 5.2: Clean Stale Worktrees
docs.text:
# Prune worktrees with missing directories
wt clean

Output:

✓ Pruned stale worktrees

docs.title: Step 5.3: Move Current Branch to Worktree
docs.text:
# On feature/something branch
wt move

Creates a worktree for your current branch. Useful for moving in-progress work to a dedicated directory.

docs.title: Pattern 1: Parallel Feature Development
docs.text:
# Terminal 1: Main feature
cc flow
# ... work on feature-a ...

# Terminal 2: Quick fix
ccw hotfix/urgent
# ... fix the bug ...
# ... commit and push ...

# Back to Terminal 1, no context lost!

docs.title: Pattern 2: Code Review
docs.text:
# Review PR in isolated worktree
ccw feature/pr-123

# Claude can help review without affecting your work
cc wt plan feature/pr-123  # Plan mode for thorough review

docs.title: Pattern 3: Experimentation
docs.text:
# Try something risky in isolated worktree
ccwy experiment/new-approach

# If it doesn't work out:
wt remove ~/.git-worktrees/project/experiment-new-approach
git branch -D experiment/new-approach

docs.title: Worktree Base Directory
docs.text:
# Default location
~/.git-worktrees/

# Customize in .zshrc
export FLOW_WORKTREE_DIR="$HOME/worktrees"

docs.title: Directory Structure
docs.text:
Worktrees are organized by project:

~/.git-worktrees/
├── flow-cli/
│   ├── feature-auth/
│   └── hotfix-urgent/
├── mediationverse/
│   └── feature-new-method/
└── my-app/
    └── feature-dashboard/

docs.title: Quick Reference
docs.text:
Command Description Version wt Formatted overview (status + session) v5.13.0 wt <project> Filter worktrees by project name v5.13.0 wt cd Navigate to worktrees folder v5.13.0 wt list Raw git worktree list output wt create <branch> Create worktree for branch wt move Move current branch to worktree wt remove <path> Remove a worktree wt clean Prune stale worktrees pick wt Interactive picker with actions v5.13.0 cc wt <branch> Launch Claude in worktree cc wt pick Pick worktree → Claude cc wt yolo <branch> Worktree + YOLO mode

Interactive Picker Keybindings (v5.13.0):

Key Action Tab Multi-select worktrees for batch ops Ctrl-X Delete selected worktree(s) Ctrl-R Refresh cache and show updated overview Enter Navigate to selected worktree

docs.title: "Branch already checked out"
docs.text:
# Can't have same branch in two worktrees
# Solution: Use a different branch name
wt create feature/auth-v2

docs.title: "Worktree not found"
docs.text:
# Prune stale references
wt clean

# Then try again
wt list

docs.title: "Not in a git repository"
docs.text:
# Worktree commands must run from a git repo
cd /path/to/your/repo
wt list

docs.title: What's Next?
docs.text:
• Git Feature Workflow - Feature branch workflow
  • CC Dispatcher Reference - Full Claude Code commands
  • Dispatcher Reference - All dispatchers

Tip: Use cc wt when you need isolation for experiments, reviews, or parallel work. The worktree stays even after Claude exits!

docs.title: Tutorial: Mastering the CC Dispatcher
docs.text:
What you'll learn: Launch Claude Code efficiently with smart project selection and mode chaining

Time: ~15 minutes | Level: Beginner to Intermediate Version: v5.8.0+

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before starting, you should:

  • [ ] Have Claude Code CLI installed (claude --version)
  • [ ] Completed: Tutorial 1: Your First Flow Session
  • [ ] Have fzf installed (optional, for pickers)

Verify your setup:

# Check cc dispatcher is available
cc help

# Check Claude CLI
claude --version

docs.title: What You'll Learn
docs.text:
By the end of this tutorial, you will:

  1. Launch Claude in different modes (acceptEdits, YOLO, plan)
  2. Use direct jump for instant project access
  3. Select models (Opus, Haiku) for different tasks
  4. Resume and continue Claude sessions
  5. Use quick actions (ask, diff, file)

docs.title: Step 1.1: Default Mode (acceptEdits)
docs.text:
The simplest way to start Claude:

# Launch Claude in current directory
cc

# Explicit HERE (same as above, more explicit)
cc .

What happens: - Claude starts with --permission-mode acceptEdits - You'll confirm file edits before they're applied - Safe for everyday work

Tip: Use cc . when you want to be explicit about launching in the current directory.

docs.title: Step 1.2: YOLO Mode (Skip Permissions)
docs.text:
For trusted tasks where you want maximum speed:

# Launch with no confirmations
cc yolo

What happens: - Claude starts with --dangerously-skip-permissions - All edits apply immediately - Use for familiar codebases and trusted operations

Warning: Only use YOLO mode when you trust the task!

docs.title: Step 1.3: Plan Mode
docs.text:
For exploration without code changes:

# Launch in planning mode
cc plan

What happens: - Claude starts with --permission-mode plan - Focus on analysis and planning - No code execution

docs.title: Step 2.1: Pick a Project (Interactive)
docs.text:
# Open project picker, then launch Claude
cc pick

What happens: 1. fzf picker shows your projects 2. Select one → cd to project 3. Claude launches in that directory

docs.title: Step 2.2: Direct Jump (Instant)
docs.text:
Skip the picker entirely:

# Jump to flow-cli → launch Claude
cc flow

# Jump to mediationverse → launch Claude
cc med

# Jump to stat-440 → launch Claude
cc stat

What happens: - Uses pick's fuzzy matching - Finds the project, cd's there - Claude launches immediately

docs.title: Step 2.3: Mode + Project Combinations
docs.text:
Chain modes with project selection:

# YOLO mode + direct jump
cc yolo flow

# Plan mode + project picker
cc plan pick

# YOLO mode + project picker
cc yolo pick

# Plan mode + direct jump
cc plan med

Pattern: cc [mode] [project|pick]

docs.title: Step 2.4: Unified Grammar (Both Orders Work!)
docs.text:
As of v5.3.0, the CC dispatcher supports unified grammar - both mode-first AND target-first orders work identically:

# These are equivalent:
cc yolo pick     # mode-first
cc pick yolo     # target-first ✨

# These are equivalent:
cc plan pick     # mode-first
cc pick plan     # target-first ✨

# These are equivalent:
cc opus pick     # mode-first
cc pick opus     # target-first ✨

Why this matters: - Type in whatever order feels natural - No more remembering "does mode come first?" - ADHD-friendly - reduce cognitive load

docs.title: Step 3.1: Use Opus for Complex Tasks
docs.text:
# Opus in current directory
cc opus

# Opus + direct jump
cc opus flow

# Opus + project picker
cc opus pick

When to use Opus: - Complex architectural decisions - Large refactoring tasks - Deep code analysis

docs.title: Step 3.2: Use Haiku for Quick Tasks
docs.text:
# Haiku in current directory
cc haiku

# Haiku + direct jump
cc haiku flow

# Haiku + project picker
cc haiku pick

When to use Haiku: - Quick questions - Simple edits - Fast feedback loops

docs.title: Step 4.1: Resume a Previous Session
docs.text:
# Show Claude session picker
cc resume

What happens: - Lists your recent Claude conversations - Select one to resume where you left off - Maintains full conversation context

docs.title: Step 4.2: Continue Most Recent
docs.text:
# Resume the most recent conversation
cc continue

What happens: - Jumps directly to your last Claude session - No picker needed - Fastest way to get back to work

docs.title: Step 5.1: Ask a Quick Question
docs.text:
# Get an answer without full session
cc ask "how do I handle missing data in R?"

What happens: - Claude answers in print mode - Non-interactive, one-shot response - Perfect for quick lookups

docs.title: Step 5.2: Review Git Changes
docs.text:
# Review uncommitted changes
cc diff

What happens: - Pipes git diff to Claude - Gets code review feedback - Great before committing

docs.title: Step 5.3: Analyze a File
docs.text:
# Analyze specific file
cc file R/myfunction.R

# With custom prompt
cc file R/myfunction.R "explain the algorithm"

What happens: - Claude analyzes the file - Provides explanation or feedback - Useful for understanding unfamiliar code

docs.title: Step 5.4: R Package Helper
docs.text:
# In an R package directory
cc rpkg "add input validation"

What happens: - Reads DESCRIPTION file - Provides package context to Claude - Claude knows the package name and structure

docs.title: Step 6.1: Launch Claude in a Worktree
docs.text:
# Create/use worktree → launch Claude
cc wt feature/auth

What happens: 1. Creates worktree if it doesn't exist 2. cd's to the worktree 3. Launches Claude there

docs.title: Step 6.2: Mode Chaining with Worktrees
docs.text:
# Worktree + YOLO
cc wt yolo feature/risky

# Worktree + Plan
cc wt plan feature/complex

# Worktree + Opus
cc wt opus feature/refactor

docs.title: Step 6.3: Pick from Existing Worktrees
docs.text:
# fzf picker for worktrees
cc wt pick

docs.title: Single-Letter Shortcuts
docs.text: Full Short Example yolo y cc y plan p cc p resume r cc r continue c cc c ask a cc a "question" file f cc f myfile.R diff d cc d opus o cc o haiku h cc h wt w cc w feature/x

docs.title: Aliases
docs.text: Alias Expands To Use Case ccy cc yolo Fast trusted work ccp cc plan Planning sessions ccr cc resume Resume conversations ccc cc continue Continue recent cco cc opus Complex tasks cch cc haiku Quick tasks ccw cc wt Worktree mode ccwy cc wt yolo Worktree + YOLO ccwp cc wt pick Worktree picker

docs.title: Morning Start
docs.text:
# Option 1: Continue where you left off
cc continue

# Option 2: Start fresh on a project
cc flow

docs.title: Feature Development
docs.text:
# Start in plan mode to think through approach
cc plan pick

# Switch to YOLO for implementation
cc yolo

docs.title: Code Review
docs.text:
# Review your changes
cc diff

# Or analyze specific file
cc file src/complex-function.js "review for bugs"

docs.title: Quick Questions
docs.text:
# Get quick answers without full session
cc ask "what's the best way to mock API calls in jest?"

docs.title: Parallel Work with Worktrees
docs.text:
# Work on feature in isolated worktree
cc wt feature/auth

# Another terminal: quick fix in different worktree
ccwy hotfix/urgent

docs.title: Which Mode?
docs.text:
What's your task?
├─ Trusted, familiar codebase
│  └─ cc yolo (or ccy)
├─ Exploring, planning
│  └─ cc plan (or ccp)
└─ Normal development
   └─ cc (default acceptEdits)

docs.title: Which Model?
docs.text:
Task complexity?
├─ Complex architecture, large refactor
│  └─ cc opus (or cco)
├─ Quick fix, simple question
│  └─ cc haiku (or cch)
└─ Normal tasks
   └─ cc (default Sonnet)

docs.title: Resume vs New Session?
docs.text:
Do you need previous context?
├─ Yes, continue discussion
│  └─ cc resume or cc continue
└─ No, fresh start
   └─ cc [mode] [project]

docs.title: "pick function not available"
docs.text:
# Verify flow-cli is loaded
source ~/.zshrc

# Or check pick command
pick help

docs.title: "claude: command not found"
docs.text:
# Install Claude CLI
# See: https://claude.ai/code

docs.title: "Not in a git repository" (for cc diff)
docs.text:
# Navigate to a git repo first
cd /path/to/your/repo
cc diff

docs.title: What's Next?
docs.text:
• Worktrees Tutorial - Deep dive into parallel development
  • CC Dispatcher Reference - Complete command reference
  • Dispatcher Reference - All flow-cli dispatchers

Tip: Start with cc for everyday work, cc yolo when you're confident, and cc opus for complex challenges!

docs.title: Tutorial: Terminal Management with TM Dispatcher
docs.text:
What you'll learn: Control your terminal appearance and context with instant shell commands

Time: ~10 minutes | Level: Beginner Version: v4.4.0+

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before starting, you should:

  • [ ] Have flow-cli installed and sourced
  • [ ] Be using a supported terminal (iTerm2, Ghostty, Kitty, etc.)
  • [ ] Optionally have aiterm installed for advanced features

Verify your setup:

# Check tm dispatcher is available
tm help

# Check which terminal you're using
tm which

docs.title: What You'll Learn
docs.text:
By the end of this tutorial, you will:

  1. Set descriptive tab/window titles
  2. Switch iTerm2 profiles for visual context
  3. Detect and apply project context
  4. Manage Ghostty themes (if using Ghostty)
  5. Use aliases for faster access

docs.title: Part 1: Shell-Native Commands (No Dependencies)
docs.text: These commands work instantly without aiterm installed.

docs.title: Step 1.1: Setting Tab Titles
docs.text:
Give your terminal tabs meaningful names:

# Set a descriptive title
tm title "Working on auth feature"

# Shorter syntax
tm t "Bug fix #123"

# Using the alias
tmt "Code review"

What happens: - Your tab/window title updates immediately - Uses universal OSC 2 escape sequence - Works in all terminals

Try it now:

tm title "Tutorial in progress"

Look at your terminal tab - it should show "Tutorial in progress"!

docs.title: Step 1.2: Switching iTerm2 Profiles (iTerm2 Only)
docs.text:
Change your terminal's visual appearance:

# Switch to a different profile
tm profile "Coding Dark"

# Back to default
tm profile "Default"

# Using shortcut
tm p "Writing"

What happens: - Colors, fonts, and settings change instantly - Profile must exist in iTerm2 preferences - Only works in iTerm2

docs.title: Step 1.3: Detecting Your Terminal
docs.text:
Find out which terminal you're running:

tm which
# → iterm2, ghostty, kitty, alacritty, wezterm, vscode, or terminal

This is useful for: - Debugging terminal-specific issues - Conditional scripts based on terminal

docs.title: Part 2: Context-Aware Features (Requires aiterm)
docs.text: These features require aiterm for intelligent context detection.

docs.title: Step 2.1: Installing aiterm
docs.text:
If you haven't installed aiterm yet:

# macOS (recommended)
brew install data-wise/tap/aiterm

# Or via pip
pip install aiterm-dev

Verify installation:

ait --version

docs.title: Step 2.2: Detecting Project Context
docs.text:
Let aiterm analyze your current directory:

tm detect

Sample output:

Terminal: iTerm2
Project: flow-cli (zsh)
Suggested: Coding profile, "flow-cli" title

docs.title: Step 2.3: Applying Context Automatically
docs.text:
Apply the detected context to your terminal:

tm switch

What happens: - Sets appropriate title based on project - Switches to matching profile (if available) - Updates status bar variables

docs.title: Step 2.4: Quick Workflow
docs.text:
Combine detection and switching:

# Start of work session
cd ~/projects/my-project
tm switch     # Apply context

# Or use the alias
tms

docs.title: Part 3: Ghostty Theme Management
docs.text: If you're using Ghostty terminal:

docs.title: Step 3.1: List Available Themes
docs.text:
tm ghost theme

Shows all 14+ built-in Ghostty themes.

docs.title: Step 3.2: Apply a Theme
docs.text:
# Try different themes
tm ghost theme tokyo-night
tm ghost theme catppuccin-mocha
tm ghost theme dracula

docs.title: Step 3.3: Check Current Font
docs.text: tm ghost font

docs.title: Step 3.4: Set Font
docs.text: tm ghost font "JetBrains Mono"

docs.title: Part 4: Using Aliases
docs.text:
Speed up your workflow with built-in aliases:

Alias Command Use For tmt tm title Quick title changes tmp tm profile Profile switching tmg tm ghost Ghostty commands tms tm switch Apply context tmd tm detect Check context

Examples:

# Quick title
tmt "Feature branch"

# Quick profile switch
tmp "Default"

# Quick context apply
tms

docs.title: Workflow 1: Starting a Work Session
docs.text:
# Navigate to project
cd ~/projects/flow-cli

# Set context
tm switch

# Or manually set title
tm title "flow-cli: adding tm dispatcher"

docs.title: Workflow 2: Multiple Tabs
docs.text:
When working with multiple terminal tabs:

# Tab 1: Main development
tm title "flow-cli: main"

# Tab 2: Tests
tm title "flow-cli: tests"

# Tab 3: Docs
tm title "flow-cli: docs"

Now you can easily identify each tab!

docs.title: Workflow 3: Visual Mode Switching
docs.text:
For iTerm2 users with custom profiles:

# Coding mode (dark theme)
tm profile "Coding Dark"

# Writing mode (light theme)
tm profile "Writing Light"

# Review mode
tm profile "Review"

docs.title: "aiterm not installed"
docs.text:
Shell-native commands still work. For full features:

brew install data-wise/tap/aiterm

docs.title: Profile switching not working
docs.text:
• Only works in iTerm2
  • Profile name must match exactly (case-sensitive)
  • Check iTerm2 Preferences → Profiles

docs.title: Ghostty commands fail
docs.text:
Ghostty support requires aiterm >= 0.3.9:

brew upgrade aiterm

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
You've learned to:

Task Command Set tab title tm title "text" or tmt "text" Switch profile tm profile "name" or tmp "name" Check terminal tm which or tmw Detect context tm detect or tmd Apply context tm switch or tms Ghostty themes tm ghost theme [name]

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Explore aiterm features: ait --help
  • Set up auto-switching: export TM_AUTO_SWITCH=1
  • Customize iTerm2 profiles for different project types
  • Read the reference: TM-DISPATCHER-REFERENCE.md

Congratulations! You've mastered terminal management with the tm dispatcher.

docs.title: Tutorial: DOT Dispatcher - Dotfile Management
docs.text: Level: Beginner Time: 30 minutes Prerequisites: chezmoi installed (brew install chezmoi)

docs.title: What You'll Learn
docs.text:
By the end of this tutorial, you'll know how to:

  • ✅ Set up chezmoi and track your first dotfile
  • ✅ Edit dotfiles with automatic change detection
  • ✅ Sync dotfiles across multiple machines
  • ✅ Use dry-run mode to preview changes safely
  • ✅ Store secrets in macOS Keychain (Touch ID, instant access)
  • ✅ Import secrets from Bitwarden to Keychain
  • ✅ Manage cloud secrets with Bitwarden (team sharing)
  • ✅ Create tokens with guided wizards (GitHub, NPM, PyPI)
  • ✅ Rotate tokens safely with --refresh
  • ✅ Sync secrets to GitHub Actions

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
# Install chezmoi (dotfile manager)
brew install chezmoi

# Initialize chezmoi (first time only)
chezmoi init

# Optional: Bitwarden CLI for secret management
brew install bitwarden-cli

docs.title: Understanding the DOT Dispatcher
docs.text:
The dot dispatcher is a wrapper around chezmoi that provides:

  • Quick status checks - See dotfile state at a glance
  • Safe editing - Preview changes before applying
  • Hash-based detection - Catches all edits, even quick ones
  • Bitwarden integration - Manage secrets securely

docs.title: Check Your Status
docs.text:
dot

Output when chezmoi is not initialized:

╭───────────────────────────────────────────────────╮
│  📁 Dotfiles Status                                │
├───────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│  State: ⚪ Not initialized                        │
│                                                   │
│  Initialize chezmoi:                              │
│    chezmoi init                                   │
╰───────────────────────────────────────────────────╯

Output when chezmoi is ready:

╭───────────────────────────────────────────────────╮
│  📁 Dotfiles Status                                │
├───────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│  State: 🟢 Synced                                 │
│  Last sync: 2 hours ago                           │
│  Tracked files: 12                                │
│                                                   │
│  Quick actions:                                   │
│    dot edit .zshrc    Edit shell config           │
│    dot sync           Pull latest changes         │
│    dot help           Show all commands           │
╰───────────────────────────────────────────────────╯

docs.title: Step 1: Add a File to Chezmoi
docs.text:
Before you can use dot edit, the file must be tracked by chezmoi:

# Add your shell config to chezmoi
chezmoi add ~/.zshrc

This copies ~/.zshrc to chezmoi's source directory (~/.local/share/chezmoi/).

docs.title: Step 2: Edit the File
docs.text:
dot edit .zshrc

What happens:

  1. Opens your $EDITOR with the source file in chezmoi's directory
  2. You make changes and save
  3. Hash-based detection determines if anything changed
  4. If changed, shows diff and prompts for action

Example session:

ℹ Opening in vim: dot_zshrc

[Editor opens, you make changes, save and exit]

✓ Changes detected!
───────────────────────────────────────────
@@ -10,6 +10,7 @@
 export PATH=$HOME/bin:$PATH
+export MY_NEW_VAR="hello"
───────────────────────────────────────────

ℹ Apply changes?
  y - Apply now
  d - Show detailed diff
  n - Keep in staging

Apply? [Y/n/d]

Options: - y (or Enter) - Apply changes to your actual ~/.zshrc - d - Show full diff, then ask again - n - Keep changes in chezmoi source (not applied yet)

docs.title: Step 3: Apply Changes Later
docs.text:
If you pressed 'n' during edit, the changes are in chezmoi's source but not yet applied to your home directory.

# See what would change
dot diff

# Apply all pending changes
dot apply

docs.title: Preview Without Applying
docs.text:
The --dry-run flag (or -n) shows what would change without actually modifying files.

dot apply --dry-run

Output when nothing to apply:

ℹ DRY-RUN MODE - No changes will be applied

✓ No pending changes

Output when changes are pending:

ℹ DRY-RUN MODE - No changes will be applied

ℹ Showing what would change (dry-run)...
[chezmoi verbose diff output]

✓ Dry-run complete - no changes applied

docs.title: When to Use Dry-Run
docs.text:
• ✅ After pulling updates from another machine
  • ✅ Before applying template changes with secrets
  • ✅ To verify changes look correct

docs.title: Initial Setup (First Machine)
docs.text:
# Initialize with a git repo
chezmoi init https://github.com/username/dotfiles.git

# Add files
chezmoi add ~/.zshrc
chezmoi add ~/.gitconfig

# Commit and push
dot push

docs.title: On Other Machines
docs.text:
# Clone your dotfiles
chezmoi init https://github.com/username/dotfiles.git

# Apply to this machine
dot apply

docs.title: Daily Sync Pattern
docs.text:
Pull changes from remote:

dot sync

Output:

ℹ Fetching from remote...

ℹ Remote has updates:
abc1234 Add new alias
def5678 Update git config

Apply updates? [Y/n/d]

Push your changes:

dot push

Output:

ℹ Staging changes...
ℹ Committing...

Commit message: [enter your message]

✓ Pushed to remote

docs.title: Part 5: macOS Keychain Secrets (v5.5.0)
docs.text:
The recommended way to manage secrets is using macOS Keychain. It provides:

  • ⚡ Instant access - No unlock step needed
  • 🍎 Touch ID / Apple Watch - Biometric authentication
  • 🔒 Auto-lock - Locks with screen lock
  • 📡 Works offline - No internet required

docs.title: Store a Secret
docs.text:
dot secret add github-token

Output:

Enter secret value: [hidden input]

✓ Secret 'github-token' stored in Keychain

docs.title: Retrieve a Secret
docs.text:
# Get a secret (Touch ID prompt may appear)
TOKEN=$(dot secret github-token)

# Use in a command
gh auth login --with-token <<< $(dot secret github-token)

docs.title: List Keychain Secrets
docs.text:
dot secret list

Output:

ℹ Secrets in Keychain (flow-cli):
  • github-token
  • npm-token
  • anthropic-api-key

docs.title: Delete a Secret
docs.text:
dot secret delete old-token

Output:

✓ Secret 'old-token' deleted

docs.title: Import from Bitwarden (One-Time Migration)
docs.text:
If you have secrets in Bitwarden, you can import them to Keychain:

# Unlock Bitwarden first
dot unlock

# Import all secrets from 'flow-cli-secrets' folder
dot secret import

Output:

ℹ Import secrets from Bitwarden folder 'flow-cli-secrets'?
Continue? [y/N] y

✓ Imported: github-token
✓ Imported: npm-token
✓ Imported: anthropic-api-key

✓ Imported 3 secret(s) to Keychain

After import, secrets are in Keychain and no longer need Bitwarden unlock.

docs.title: Part 6: Bitwarden Cloud Secrets (Alternative)
docs.text: If you need cloud-synced secrets (team sharing, multiple devices), use Bitwarden:

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
brew install bitwarden-cli

# Login (first time)
bw login

docs.title: Unlock Vault
docs.text:
dot unlock

Output:

ℹ Enter your Bitwarden master password:
[password prompt]

✓ Vault unlocked successfully

  Session active in this shell only
ℹ Use 'dot secret <name>' to retrieve secrets

docs.title: List Secrets
docs.text:
dot secret list

Output:

ℹ Retrieving items from vault...

🔑 github-token (Work/GitHub)
🔑 npm-token (Work/Node)
🔑 anthropic-api-key (AI/Keys)
📝 ssh-passphrase (SSH)

ℹ Usage: dot secret <name>

docs.title: Retrieve a Secret
docs.text:
# Retrieve without echo (secure)
TOKEN=$(dot secret github-token)

# Use in a command
curl -H "Authorization: Bearer $TOKEN" https://api.github.com/user

docs.title: Using Secrets in Templates
docs.text:
Create a template file in chezmoi:

File: ~/.local/share/chezmoi/dot_zshrc.tmpl

# API Keys (from Bitwarden)
export GITHUB_TOKEN="{{ bitwarden "item" "github-token" }}"
export ANTHROPIC_API_KEY="{{ bitwarden "item" "anthropic-api-key" }}"

Apply with secrets:

# Unlock vault first

docs.title: Tutorial: Prompt Dispatcher - Manage Your Shell Prompt
docs.text: Level: Beginner Time: 15 minutes Prerequisites: At least one prompt engine installed

docs.title: What You'll Learn
docs.text:
By the end of this tutorial, you'll know how to:

  • ✅ Check which prompt engine is currently active
  • ✅ Switch between prompt engines instantly
  • ✅ Use the interactive toggle menu
  • ✅ Preview changes with dry-run mode
  • ✅ Set up Oh My Posh from scratch
  • ✅ Troubleshoot common prompt issues

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
You need at least one of these prompt engines installed:

# Option 1: Powerlevel10k (via ZSH plugin manager)
# Add to ~/.config/zsh/.zsh_plugins.txt:
romkatv/powerlevel10k

# Option 2: Starship
brew install starship

# Option 3: Oh My Posh
brew install oh-my-posh

docs.title: Understanding the Prompt Dispatcher
docs.text:
The prompt dispatcher lets you:

  • Switch prompt engines - Change from Powerlevel10k to Starship to Oh My Posh
  • Preview changes - See what will happen before committing
  • Set up new engines - Guided wizard for Oh My Posh

docs.title: Check Your Current Status
docs.text:
prompt status

Example output:

ℹ Prompt Engines:

  ● Powerlevel10k (current)
    Feature-rich, highly customizable
    Config: ~/.config/zsh/.p10k.zsh

  ○ Starship
    Minimal, fast Rust-based
    Config: ~/.config/starship.toml

  ○ Oh My Posh
    Modular with extensive themes
    Config: ~/.config/ohmyposh/config.json

To switch: prompt toggle

The ● indicates your current engine; ○ shows available alternatives.

docs.title: Method 1: Interactive Menu
docs.text:
The easiest way to switch is using the toggle command:

prompt toggle

You'll see:

Which prompt engine would you like to use?

1) starship
2) ohmyposh
#?

Enter the number of your choice and press Enter. The shell will reload automatically.

docs.title: Method 2: Direct Switch
docs.text:
If you know which engine you want, switch directly:

# Switch to Starship
prompt starship

# Switch to Powerlevel10k
prompt p10k

# Switch to Oh My Posh
prompt ohmyposh

Output:

✓ Switched to Starship
Reloading shell...

docs.title: Using Dry-Run Mode
docs.text:
Not sure what will happen? Preview first:

prompt --dry-run starship

Output:

🔍 DRY RUN MODE - No changes will be made

Would perform the following actions:
  1. Set environment variable: FLOW_PROMPT_ENGINE="starship"
  2. Switch prompt engine to: Starship
  3. Reload shell with new configuration

Config file: ~/.config/starship.toml

To apply these changes, run:
  prompt starship

docs.title: Preview Toggle Options
docs.text:
prompt --dry-run toggle

Output:

🔍 DRY RUN MODE - No changes will be made

Current engine: Powerlevel10k

Available alternatives to switch to:
  1) Starship
  2) Oh My Posh

To switch engines, run:
  prompt toggle

docs.title: Part 4: Setting Up Oh My Posh
docs.text: If you haven't configured Oh My Posh yet, use the setup wizard:

docs.title: Step 1: Run the Setup Wizard
docs.text:
prompt setup-ohmyposh

Output:

ℹ Oh My Posh Configuration Wizard

✓ Created ~/.config/ohmyposh
✓ Configuration created at ~/.config/ohmyposh/config.json

Next steps:
  1. Customize your config: nano ~/.config/ohmyposh/config.json
  2. Validate: oh-my-posh config
  3. Switch to OhMyPosh: prompt ohmyposh

docs.title: Step 2: Switch to Oh My Posh
docs.text: prompt ohmyposh

docs.title: Step 3: Customize (Optional)
docs.text:
Edit the config file to customize your prompt:

nano ~/.config/ohmyposh/config.json

Or browse the Oh My Posh themes for inspiration.

docs.title: Table View
docs.text:
Get a tabular overview of all engines:

prompt list

Output:

ℹ Available Prompt Engines:

name               active     config file
─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Powerlevel10k      ●          ~/.config/zsh/.p10k.zsh
Starship           ○          ~/.config/starship.toml
Oh My Posh         ○          ~/.config/ohmyposh/config.json

Legend: ● = current, ○ = available

docs.title: Engine Not Found
docs.text:
Problem:

✗ Starship not found in PATH
Install with: brew install starship

Solution:

brew install starship

docs.title: Config Missing
docs.text:
Problem:

⚠ OhMyPosh config missing at ~/.config/ohmyposh/config.json

Solution:

prompt setup-ohmyposh

docs.title: Prompt Doesn't Change After Switch
docs.text:
Problem: You switched but the prompt looks the same.

Solution: Force a shell reload:

exec zsh -i

Or simply open a new terminal tab.

docs.title: Check What's Set
docs.text:
echo $FLOW_PROMPT_ENGINE

This should show powerlevel10k, starship, or ohmyposh.

docs.title: Quick Reference
docs.text: Task Command See current engine prompt status Switch interactively prompt toggle Switch to Starship prompt starship Switch to Powerlevel10k prompt p10k Switch to Oh My Posh prompt ohmyposh Preview a switch prompt --dry-run <engine> Set up Oh My Posh prompt setup-ohmyposh List all engines prompt list Show help prompt help

docs.title: Engine Comparison
docs.text: Feature Powerlevel10k Starship Oh My Posh Speed ⚡⚡⚡ Very fast ⚡⚡⚡⚡ Fastest ⚡⚡ Fast Customization Excellent Good Extensive Themes Many built-in Many presets 100+ official Config Format ZSH script TOML JSON/YAML Best For Feature-rich Speed-focused Theme exploration

docs.title: What's Next?
docs.text:
Now that you can manage your prompt engine, try:

  1. Experiment - Try each engine for a day
  2. Customize - Edit the config files to match your style
  3. Check health - Run flow doctor to verify prompt setup

docs.text:

  • Prompt Quick Reference Card - Quick lookup
